metadata.description:
This data is the data of the automatic weather station (AWS, Campbell company) set up in Yigong Zangbu basin by the Southeast Tibet alpine environment comprehensive observation and research station of Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2018. The geographic coordinates are 30.1741 n, 94.9334 e, and the altitude is 2282m. The underlying surface is grassland.
The data include daily arithmetic mean data of air temperature (℃), relative humidity (%), wind speed (M / s), water vapor pressure (kPa) and air pressure (MB) and daily accumulated value of precipitation. The original data is an average value recorded in 10 minutes. The temperature and humidity are measured by hmp155a temperature and humidity probe. The rainfall instrument is tb4, the atmospheric pressure sensor is ptb210, and the wind speed sensor is 05103. These probes are 2 m above the ground. Data quality: the quality of the original data is better, less missing. The data station is a meteorological station in the lower altitude of the Qinghai Tibet Plateau, which will be updated from time to time in the future. It can be used by researchers studying climate, hydrology, glaciers, etc.

background: In mountainous areas, different altitudes exhibit distinct vertical zonation due to variations in water (precipitation) and heat (temperature) components. The Sejila Mountain in southeastern Tibet has a pronounced mountain vertical zonation feature: from the foot of the mountain to the summit, the vegetation types include broadleaf forest, mixed coniferous-broadleaf forest, coniferous forest, shrubs, and moss. The vegetation types in Sejila Mountain are diverse, and the longevity of trees is notable (Lu et al., 2015). The tree line at 4390 m is one of the highest forest tree lines in the world, making it a hotspot for tree-ring and forest ecology research (Wang et al., 2014; Liang et al., 2016; Shen et al., 2018). Currently, there is limited research on the vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation in Sejila Mountain (Liang et al., 2011). Most studies by some scholars on the changes in temperature and precipitation vertical gradients in this region and its vicinity are primarily based on the data from the Bayi Station (formerly Linzhi Station) and the nearby Bomi Station, focusing on the vertical lapse rate of temperature across the entire Tibetan Plateau (Jiang Jingchao et al., 2016; Guo et al., 2016; Li et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2001, 2018; Zhang et al., 2018) and precipitation gradients (Guo et al., 2016).
research objective: Therefore, this article explores the vertical variation patterns of temperature and precipitation on the eastern and western slopes of the Sejila Mountain based on temperature and precipitation data from 11 meteorological stations. This not only deepens the understanding of the influence of slope orientation on the vertical gradient changes of temperature and precipitation in Sejila Mountain, but also helps to better understand the physiological and ecological characteristics of plant and animal distribution with altitude changes in the region. Additionally, it provides reliable data support for future hydrological modeling in this watershed area.
challenges: Due to the many factors affecting the vertical temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient, among the meteorological stations in the Sejila Mountains, except for the mountain pass station, tree line station, and ecological station located on the ridge, all other stations are situated in valley areas. Additionally, the western slope and high-altitude stations are relatively few, which may affect the accuracy of the temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient obtained in this study.
methods: The data for this study includes daily temperature and precipitation records (from April to October) from 2013 to 2018 provided by the Linzhi Meteorological Bureau of the Tibet Autonomous Region for nine stations: Bayi, Niche, Station 114, Station 113, Shankou, Ecological Station, Rulang, Bingzhan, and Layue, as well as the main station of Southeast Tibet Station (shown in Figure 1 and Table 1) and two stations at the tree line. Based on the geographical locations of these stations, the stations in the Sejila Mountain area are divided into two natural geographical units according to slope orientation: the west slope (south slope) and the east slope (north slope). The temperature vertical lapse rate and precipitation gradient are estimated, with the Sejila Mountain Pass station belonging to both the west and east slopes. The temperature vertical lapse rate and precipitation gradient are estimated through regression analysis based on the elevation of the stations and the temperature or precipitation amounts.
dataset: The data for this study includes daily temperature and precipitation values (from April to October) from 2013 to 2018 provided by the Linzhi Meteorological Bureau of the Tibet Autonomous Region for nine stations: Bayi, Niche, Station 114, Station 113, Shankou, Ecological Station, Rulang, Bing Station, and Laye Station, as well as the main station of Southeast Tibet Station (shown in Figure 1 and Table 1) and two stations at the tree line.
findings: From 2013 to 2018, the average temperature lapse rate (λ) at 11 stations on the Selila Mountain ranged from 0.59 to 0.63 °C·(100 m)^-1, with the lowest λ value in 2016 and the highest in 2014. The average λ from 2013 to 2018 was 0.60 °C·(100 m)^-1. The western slope had λ values ranging from 0.69 to 0.72 °C·(100 m)^-1, with the lowest λ in 2016 and the highest in 2014, and the average λ from 2013 to 2018 was 0.71 °C·(100 m)^-1. The eastern slope had λ values between 0.53 and 0.55 °C·(100 m)^-1. Unlike the Selila Mountain and the western slope, the lowest λ in the eastern slope occurred in 2015, while the highest was in 2017, with an average λ of 0.55 °C·(100 m)^-1 from 2013 to 2018. From 2013 to 2018, the average precipitation gradient on the eastern slope was 10.5 mm·(100 m)^-1, with the monsoon period showing a trend of first increasing, then decreasing, and then increasing again with elevation; the non-monsoon period exhibited a trend of first decreasing and then increasing. The precipitation gradient above the southeastern Tibet station was notably significant.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to gather meteorological data in mountainous regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used in mountainous regions like the Tibetan Plateau is the use of automatic weather stations (AWS) set up in specific locations such as the Yigong Zangbu Basin. These stations collect data on temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, water vapor pressure, and atmospheric pressure every 10 minutes using various sensors positioned 2 meters above the ground.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when estimating temperature and precipitation gradients in mountain regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge faced when estimating temperature and precipitation gradients in mountain regions is the limited number of meteorological stations at higher altitudes, which can affect the accuracy of the vertical lapse rate and precipitation gradient calculations. Additionally, most stations are located in valley areas rather than at diverse elevations, which may not represent the true environmental conditions of the region.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the main characteristics of the meteorological data collected at the automatic weather station in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Feature Specification.Answer: temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, water vapor pressure, atmospheric pressure, accumulated precipitation, recorded every 10 minutes, sensors placed 2 meters above the ground

Definition.Question: What does '气温垂直递减率' mean in the context of meteorological data collection?
Definition.Answer: In the context of meteorological data collection, '气温垂直递减率' refers to the rate at which temperature decreases with an increase in altitude. It is calculated through regression analysis of temperature data from meteorological stations at different altitudes.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods for meteorological data at lower altitudes in the Tibetan Plateau compare to those at higher altitudes in terms of measurement tools and data accuracy?
Comparison.Answer: The meteorological station at a lower altitude on the Tibetan Plateau uses various sensors, such as the HMP155A for temperature and humidity, PTB210 for atmospheric pressure, and 05103 for wind speed, situated 2 meters above ground. The original data quality is considered good with minimal missing data, which might differ from higher altitude stations where environmental factors can affect accuracy and the choice of measurement tools.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the challenges faced when estimating the vertical temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient in mountain regions like the Tibetan Plateau compared to other mountainous regions?
Comparison.Answer: In the Tibetan Plateau, factors influencing the vertical temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient include the location of meteorological stations, most being valley-based, and the number of stations on the western slope and high altitudes being fewer. These challenges may differ in other mountainous regions where station distribution and environmental influences might vary, impacting the accuracy of lapse rate and gradient estimates.

Interpretation.Question: How might the placement and number of meteorological stations affect the accuracy and reliability of data on temperature and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The placement and number of meteorological stations significantly influence data reliability. Stations located in valleys versus those on ridges yield varied results due to topographical influences. For example, fewer stations on the western slope and at higher altitudes may affect the accuracy of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients, potentially leading to less representative data for these areas.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying effects of slope orientation on climatic data can be inferred from datasets collected on different mountain slopes?
Interpretation.Answer: Slope orientation impacts climatic data, as evidenced by different temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients on eastern and western slopes. The eastern slope shows a mean temperature lapse rate of 0.55℃ per 100 meters, while the western slope exhibits a higher rate of 0.71℃ per 100 meters. This suggests that slope orientation influences microclimatic conditions, affecting the rate of temperature decrease and precipitation distribution.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in accurately determining temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Factors such as the majority of weather stations being located in valleys rather than ridge areas, the scarcity of stations on the western slope and at higher altitudes, and the numerous influences on temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients contribute to challenges in accurately determining these metrics in mountainous regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are there variations in the temperature lapse rate across different slopes of a mountain range?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Variations in the temperature lapse rate across different slopes can be attributed to the natural geographic division of the mountain stations into western and eastern slopes, which affects the temperature vertical gradient due to differences in slope exposure and altitude.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors influence the decision to install meteorological sensors at specific altitudes in a mountainous region?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The decision to install meteorological sensors at specific altitudes is influenced by the need to capture diverse climatic conditions across different elevations and slopes, as well as logistical considerations like accessibility and the aim to monitor specific ecological zones such as tree lines and valleys.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects of the limited number of high-altitude stations on the reliability of temperature lapse rate estimates in mountainous environments?
Causal Consequence.Answer: A limited number of high-altitude stations can reduce the reliability of temperature lapse rate estimates, as these stations are crucial for capturing the temperature variations that occur with changes in altitude. This limitation may lead to an underestimation or overestimation of temperature decreases with altitude, impacting ecological research and climate modeling that rely on accurate lapse rate data.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind collecting meteorological data at the Zangdongnan station, and how do these objectives influence the choice of instruments and data collection methods?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of collecting meteorological data at the Zangdongnan station is to provide reliable data for research in climate, hydrology, and glaciology. This influences the choice of instruments and methods to ensure accurate and comprehensive data, such as using specific sensors for temperature, humidity, wind speed, vapor pressure, and atmospheric pressure, and ensuring data quality by minimizing missing data.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to understand the vertical temperature and precipitation gradients in the Sejila Mountain region, and how does this understanding contribute to ecological or hydrological research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Understanding the vertical temperature and precipitation gradients in the Sejila Mountain region is crucial for gaining insights into the physiological and ecological characteristics of plant and animal distributions along altitudinal gradients. It also supports future hydrological modeling in the area by providing data on how these gradients influence water distribution and availability.

Goal Orientation.Question: What motivated the analysis of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients across different slopes in the Sejila Mountain, and how do these analyses aid in addressing the challenges faced by researchers in this region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The analysis of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients across different slopes in the Sejila Mountain was motivated by the need to deepen the understanding of how slope orientation affects these variables. This aids researchers in overcoming challenges related to the limited number of high-altitude stations and the influence of various factors on temperature and precipitation, providing a more realistic estimate of these gradients.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approaches are used to estimate temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients based on meteorological data from multiple stations in a mountainous region?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The estimation of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients involves regression analysis based on the altitude and weather data from multiple meteorological stations, divided into natural geographic units like slopes.

Enablement.Question: What data collection techniques enable the accurate measurement of meteorological variables like temperature and humidity in high-altitude regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of automatic weather stations (AWS) equipped with specific sensors such as HMP155A for temperature and humidity, TB4 for precipitation, PTB210 for atmospheric pressure, and 05103 for wind speed enables accurate measurements. These sensors are positioned at 2 meters above the ground, which is crucial for collecting reliable data in high-altitude regions.

Enablement.Question: What challenges might arise from using data from meteorological stations located in different geographical units, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include potential inaccuracies in estimating temperature decrement rates and precipitation gradients due to factors like uneven distribution of stations across ridges and valleys, and a limited number of high-altitude stations. These challenges can be addressed by ensuring a more uniform distribution of stations and increasing the number of stations at higher altitudes to improve data representativeness.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset from mountainous regions present challenges in accurately estimating temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients?
Expectation.Answer: The factors influencing temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions are numerous, and most meteorological stations, except for a few located on ridges, are situated in valleys. Additionally, the number of stations on the western slope and at high altitudes is limited, which may affect the accuracy of the estimated temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients.

Expectation.Question: Why might a research approach focus on splitting a region into different geographical units when analyzing temperature and precipitation data?
Expectation.Answer: Splitting a region into different geographical units, such as differentiating between western and eastern slopes, allows for a more detailed understanding of how slope direction affects vertical changes in temperature and precipitation gradients. This segmentation helps in recognizing specific climatic characteristics and provides reliable data for ecological and hydrological modeling.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in obtaining accurate vertical temperature and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions like the southeast Tibet area?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges include the varied factors affecting vertical temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients, such as the location of meteorological stations primarily in valley areas, the limited number of stations on the western slope and at high altitudes, and the geographical distribution of stations on the mountain ridges, which may impact the accuracy of the temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients obtained.

Judgmental.Question: How might researchers approach the integration of data from multiple meteorological stations to enhance the reliability of climate models in diverse topographical zones like southeast Tibet?
Judgmental.Answer: Researchers can integrate data by using regression analysis based on station altitude and climate variables, categorizing stations into natural geographical units such as different slopes, and validating models with historical data from multiple years to improve reliability and provide a comprehensive understanding of climate dynamics affected by topography.

Assertion.Answer: Data from multiple meteorological stations can be integrated by using regression analysis based on the geographical positions and elevations of the stations to estimate temperature and precipitation gradients. This approach allows researchers to analyze the vertical changes in temperature and precipitation across different slopes and altitudes.

Assertion.Answer: Challenges in ensuring accuracy include the placement of stations, as most are located in valley areas rather than ridges, which might affect the data's representation of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients. Additionally, the limited number of high-altitude stations can impact the reliability of the findings.
